content.webTitle: Dele Alli draws plaudits as Tottenham profit from trip to Palace

fields.headline: Dele Alli draws plaudits as Tottenham profit from trip to Palace
fields.bodyText: Mauricio Pochettino has played down suggestions Dele Alli almost signed for Liverpool by claiming his former club Espanyol came close to agreeing a deal for Lionel Messi when the forward was a teenager. Alli’s wonder strike at Crystal Palace earned Tottenham a fine win, having gone behind in the first half following an own goal by Jan Vertonghen. The game was poised at 1-1 after a Harry Kane equaliser when three golden touches from Alli produced what could be the goal of the season, a volley from 20 yards that left mouths gaping. Brendan Rodgers, the former Liverpool manager, claimed last week he almost signed Alli from MK Dons before the midfielder moved to Spurs. Pochettino said players often speak with a number of clubs before settling on a decision, saying Messi came close to joining Barcelona’s city rivals Espanyol at 17. “Do you know how many players in football are close to signing for many clubs,” said Pochettino, whose son Sebastiano – a sports scientist – was sat behind the Spurs dugout on Saturday. “Dele Alli, it’s impossible to speak about that because maybe different clubs are close to signing Dele Alli, it’s like Harry Kane, it’s like different players, it’s only one comment from some manager. Dele Alli now is here. “We were close at Espanyol to signing Lionel Messi. Messi was 17 years old, playing for the under-18s and was very close to signing for Espanyol. It was close but it never happened.” On Alli’s strike, he said: “I prefer that he scores goals like today, it was fantastic. We try to push the players to try. To do whatever they can. You never can stop the quality that they have, they have natural skills to play football and you need to give them a professional side but cannot stop natural talent because they are very creative.” Alli’s goal with six minutes remaining ensured Tottenham extended their lead over fifth-placed Manchester United to five points. Nacer Chadli also had a major impact on the game, crossing for Kane to head in the equaliser before scoring a screamer himself in injury time from 25 yards. The winger said: “Dele is always scoring volleys in training. He’s very good at them and practises a lot so the fact it has happened in a game is not lucky. It was a fantastic goal, unbelievable. “I’ve been very impressed with him. He is still young but he plays like he has a lot of experience. He has a lot of potential and if he fulfils half of it he will be a great player. “He is a very skilful player and tough also, he has everything in his locker. As a young player you always have to work hard and I think he knows that. The way he is playing he is going to be picked [for England] for sure.” Vertonghen has undergone scans on ankle and knee injuries sustained in a collision with the Palace striker Connor Wickham, who appeared to elbow the defender in the face. Alan Pardew said he did not see the incident but criticised Alli for a tackle on Yohan Cabaye during the second half. No Palace player has scored in the league since mid-December, and Pardew is hoping to secure a deal for Emmanuel Adebayor before the end of the January transfer window. The Wolfsburg striker Nicklas Bendtner has also been linked with a move to Palace. With Roy Hodgson in the stands to watch Alli’s goal and a number of other English players on the pitch, Pardew believes things are looking bright for England at Euro 2016. The Palace manager said: “We’ve produced a lot of good English players recently, it was only 18 months ago we were all moaning about where is the new talent. “Suddenly we have an abundance of talent; [Oxlade-]Chamberlain, Walcott, Dele Alli, Harry Kane, Vardy. Suddenly we’ve got a lot of pace and energy and if I was him [Hodgson] I’d be chortling and chuckling all the way to the summer. I’m sure he enjoyed the goal. He had no pressure on him today but for me it was a horrible goal.” Man of the match: Dele Alli (Tottenham)
